Odslej lahko samostojno vlada
Belgijska prestolonaslednica Elisabeth je 18. rojstni dan zaznamovala z državniškim banketom. Bo prva belgijska vladarica, ki ji je bilo to določeno z rojstvom, ne s poroko.
02 Nov 2019, 11:05 by B. K. P.
Belgijska princesa in prestolonaslednica Elisabeth je pred dnevi dopolnila 18 let. Tega pomembnega mejnika pa mladenka, ki je ob tej priložnosti pripotovala iz angleškega Walesa, kjer obiskuje šolo, ni zaznamovala z običajno zabavo, temveč so ji v kraljevi palači v Bruslju pripravili pravi državniški banket, ki ga je predvajala celo nacionalna televizija. Samo za princeso so nastopile članice kraljevega baleta, zapela ji je nekdanja evrovizijska zvezdnica Blanche.Slavljenki sta se seveda pridružila mama in oče, ki sta bila neizmerno ponosna, kraljica Mathilde je komaj zadrževala solze, ko je poslušala hčerin govor, oče pa ji je pripel medaljo Leopoldovega viteškega reda, ustanovljenega leta 1832, ko je Belgija postala samostojna; gre za najvišje viteško odlikovanje v Belgiji. Elisabethin 18. rojstni dan je bil deležen tako veliko pozornosti, ker lahko zdaj, ko je polnoletna, sama prevzame prestol in samostojno vlada.
Oče je Elisabeth pripel medaljo Leopoldovega viteškega reda, najvišje viteško odlikovanje v Belgiji.
Če bi kralj odstopil ali umrl pred njeno polnoletnostjo, bi ji namreč moral pri vodenju pomagati svetovalec. Še posebno pomemben pa bo dan, ko bo postala kraljica. Princesa bo namreč prva belgijska kraljica, ki bo to postala z rojstvom, ne poroko, vse dosedanje belgijske kraljice so bile kraljeve žene. Ob ustanovitvi leta 1839 je belgijska ustava določala, da lahko prestol zasedejo le moški potomci kralja Leopolda I., a to ne velja več od leta 1991, ko je začel veljati t. i. Salijski zakon, ki dovoljuje tudi ženskim, da zasedejo prestol.

From now on it can rule independently
Belgian Crown Prince Elisabeth marked her 18th birthday with a national banquet. She will be the first Belgian ruler to whom this was determined by birth, not marriage.
02 Nov 2019, 11:05 by B. K. P.
The Belgian princess and Crown Prince Elisabeth turned 18 days ago. This important milestone, however, was not marked by a young girl who had traveled from English to Wales while attending school, but at the Royal Palace in Brussels she had a real national banquet broadcast by even national television. Members of the Royal Ballet performed for the princess only, and former Eurovision star Blanche sang to her. The mother-and-father were joined, of course, with immense pride, Queen Mathilde barely holding back tears as she listened to her daughter's speech, and her father brought her the Leopold Knight Order Medal, established in 1832 when Belgium became independent; it is the highest knighthood in Belgium. Elisabeth's 18th birthday has received so much attention because now that she is of age she can take over the throne and rule on her own.
Elisabeth's father brought the Leopold Knight Order Medal, Belgium's highest knighthood.
If the king resigned or died before she came of age, she would have to be assisted by a counselor. Of particular importance will be the day she becomes queen. The princess will be the first Belgian queen to become this by birth, not marriage, until now the Belgian queens have been royal wives. Founded in 1839, the Belgian constitution provided that only male descendants of King Leopold I could occupy the throne, but this has not been the case since 1991, when t. i. Salian law that also allows women to occupy the throne.
